verses.text: Dead flies cause the perfumer’s oil to give off a foul odor; so a little foolishness outweighs wisdom and honor.
verses.comment: Just as a few dead flies spoil precious perfume, so even a small amount of foolish behavior can overshadow years of wise living. Sin, even if 'small,' damages a person's reputation and spiritual health. This also hints at the need for holiness and vigilance—ideas strongly emphasized throughout the biblical tradition.

verses.text: A wise person’s heart leans to the right, but a fool’s heart to the left.
verses.comment: The right side is often associated with favor or strength (cf. Matthew 25:33). Wisdom leads to right and good decisions, while folly leads to error. The imagery calls to mind the necessity of forming one’s conscience correctly, a process vital to true holiness.

verses.text: Even as the fool walks along the road, his lack of sense shows, and he says to everyone that he is a fool.
verses.comment: Foolishness cannot be hidden for long; it reveals itself in actions and words (cf. James 3:13). This verse cautions believers to seek true wisdom not just in intellect, but also in their daily walk.

verses.text: If the spirit of a ruler rises against you, do not leave your place; calmness can lay to rest great offenses.
verses.comment: Patience and humility, especially under unjust authority, can prevent greater harm (cf. 1 Peter 2:18-20). Note the wisdom in enduring for the sake of harmony—which echoes Christ's teaching on meekness in the Beatitudes.

verses.text: There is an evil I have seen under the sun, like an error made by rulers:
verses.comment: Human governance is often corrupted by mistakes and sin. The Preacher prepares to describe injustices that point beyond mere human virtue toward the need for ultimate, unerring justice.

verses.text: Fools are set in many high positions, but the rich sit in low places.
verses.comment: The inversion of social order—where the unworthy hold authority—runs contrary to wisdom. This expresses a hidden longing for a kingdom of true justice. Spiritually, it hints at the paradox of the humble being exalted, as in Luke 1:52.

verses.text: I have seen slaves riding on horses and princes walking like slaves on the ground.
verses.comment: This continues the theme of role reversal. There is an implicit call to humility; as Christ himself was exalted through humility (Philippians 2:6-11).

verses.text: Whoever digs a pit may fall into it, and whoever breaks through a wall may be bitten by a snake.
verses.comment: The verse alludes to the dangers of plotting evil: often, harm rebounds on the schemer (cf. Matthew 7:2). Sinful motives are self-destructive, showing both literal and spiritual consequences.

verses.text: Whoever quarries stones may be hurt by them; whoever splits logs may be endangered by them.
verses.comment: Even honest labor involves risk; wisdom means acting prudently. Spiritually, all human effort is in need of grace to be truly fruitful and safe.

verses.text: If an iron axe is blunt and one does not sharpen its edge, then more strength must be used, but wisdom brings success.
verses.comment: Wisdom is like sharpening an axe—effort alone without preparation brings little profit. This alludes to the value of ongoing spiritual formation, sacraments, and means of grace for fruitful Christian life.

verses.text: If the snake bites before it is charmed, there is no benefit to the charmer.
verses.comment: Timing and preparedness are crucial. If advice or action comes too late, it is useless. This verse may be read as a call to readiness and timely spiritual discernment.

verses.text: The words of a wise person bring favor, but the lips of a fool consume him.
verses.comment: Speech reveals character: wise words bless, while foolish words destroy (cf. James 3:5-10). Christ’s own words were recognized for their authority and grace (Luke 4:22).

verses.text: The beginning of the words from his mouth is foolishness, and the end of his talk is wicked madness.
verses.comment: Foolish talk escalates into actual harm and sin. Each careless word can lead away from the path of holiness (cf. Matthew 12:36).

verses.text: A fool multiplies words, though no one knows what will happen, and who can tell him what is to come after him?
verses.comment: The fool presumes to speak of the future, not understanding its mystery. True wisdom recognizes our dependence on God’s providence and the limits of human knowledge.

verses.text: The labor of fools wearies them, for they do not even know the way to the city.
verses.comment: Fools are exhausted by fruitless effort, losing even basic direction. 'The city' may symbolize the promised destination or ultimate goal—the Kingdom. This is a subtle nod to the truth that guided community and tradition keep the believer on the right path.

verses.text: Woe to you, O land, when your king is a child, and your princes feast in the morning!
verses.comment: Immaturity and self-indulgence in leadership bring woe to a nation. This imagery also reminds believers to pray for righteous, wise authority in the Church and in civil society.

verses.text: Blessed are you, O land, when your king is the son of nobles, and your princes feast at the proper time—for strength and not for drunkenness!
verses.comment: Good order in governance, feasting with restraint, brings blessing. This principle applies to earthly rulers and, spiritually, to the shepherds of the Church, who should care for the flock out of virtue and self-control.

verses.text: Because of laziness the roof sinks in, and through idle hands the house leaks.
verses.comment: Neglect leads to ruin. Applied spiritually, this teaches vigilance in maintaining one’s faith and the life of the Christian community (cf. Matthew 25:1-13 and the parable of the wise and foolish virgins).

verses.text: A feast is made for laughter, and wine makes life glad, but money is the answer for everything.
verses.comment: Though practical realities like money are necessary, the verse is likely satirical—pointing to the limits of earthly solutions. True joy comes from right relationship with God, not from possessions alone.

verses.text: Do not curse the king, even in your thoughts, nor curse the rich in your bedroom; for a bird of the air may carry your voice, and some winged creature may tell the matter.
verses.comment: Respect for authority—even in private—is wise, as nothing is truly secret (cf. Luke 12:2-3). This mirrors Christ’s command to obedience and right speech, and the importance of interior holiness that aligns with exterior deeds.
